chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: How should I manage a child with confirmed autism spectrum disorder in primary care?
chapter.summary: Covers the primary care management of a child or young person with confirmed ASD. It also includes brief information on the role of secondary care in the management of ASD in a child or young person.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a child or young person with confirmed autism spectrum disorder?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Following confirmation of the diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in secondary care, the decision to routinely review children or young people with ASD in primary care (to ensure that they, and their family, are coping well and receiving appropriate medical, educational, and social support) should be made on a case by case basis using clinical judgement.
    • Review in primary care may not be appropriate in all cases, for example in:
      • Children or young people who are under regular specialist review, or
      • Children or young people and their families who are coping well with the current support they are receiving and are well informed about how to access additional support if needed.
  • Ensure all children and young people with ASD and an associated mental health, behavioural, or neurodevelopmental disorder are reviewed by a specialist if symptoms are of sufficient severity to significantly impact their wellbeing or that of their family and/or carers. This includes those with ASD and:
    • Anxiety.
    • Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
    • Oppositional defiant disorder.
    • A learning (intellectual) disability.
    • Epilepsy.
  • Ensure that the parents and/or carers of a child or young person with ASD are well informed about the condition and about available support. This should include:
    • How to contact the child or young person's key worker (if they have one) for advice.
    • How to request a special educational needs assessment for the child or young person (if they have not received one) and how this can lead to supporting learning needs.
      • GOV.UK (www.gov.uk) has information on Special educational needs and disabilities (SEND).
    • Ensuring they are aware of the benefits they are entitled to. 
      • The National Autistic Society website (www.autism.org.uk) has information on Benefits for children with autism (aged under 16 years) and Benefits for young people with autism (aged 16–20 years). There is also information on Commmunity care options for children, Support for young people in transition, Support for carers, Direct payments, Managing money, and Social care advice services.
    • How to arrange a carers' assessment if they are a parent or carer providing regular and substantial care to a disabled child or young person (including a child or young person with a mental disability).
      • This may help the parent and/or carer get support to maintain their own health and to balance caring with other aspects of their lives (such as work and family life). It may also allow them to access respite care.
      • The NHS website (www.nhs.uk) has information on Carer's assessments.
    • How to obtain more information on all aspects of ASD, including living with ASD, schools and services for people with ASD, and working with people with ASD. Information on ASD is available from:
      • The National Autistic Society website (www.autism.org.uk).
      • The NHS website (www.nhs.uk).
  • Manage sleep problems or behaviour that challenges, if present.
  • Ensure that young people with ASD are reassessed in secondary care to establish the need for continuing treatment into adulthood. This assessment should ideally take place around the age of 14 years.
  • Sources of information for healthcare professionals include:
    • The Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP, www.rcgp.org.uk) — the Autistic Spectrum Disorders Toolkit provides a guide to autism for primary care professionals, people affected by autism, clinical commissioning groups, and members of the general public.
    • The National Autistic Society (www.autism.org.uk) — the Autism guidance for health professionals is aimed at all health professionals who may come into contact with a child or adult with autism for reasons other than autism.
    • The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE, www.nice.org.uk):
      • The guideline on Challenging behaviour and learning disabilities: prevention and interventions for people with learning disabilities whose behaviour challenges covers interventions and support for children, young people, and adults with a learning disability and behaviour that challenges. It also covers support and intervention for family members and/or carers.
      • The guideline on Learning disabilities and behaviour that challenges: service design and delivery covers services for children, young people, and adults with a learning disability (or autism and a learning disability) and behaviour that challenges.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based largely on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines Autism. The management and support of children and young people on the autism spectrum [National Collaborating Centre for Mental Health, 2013] and Autism spectrum disorder in under 19s: support and management [NICE, 2017]. 

When to arrange routine review of a child or young person with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in primary care
  • This recommendation is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Review of children or young people with ASD and an associated mental health or behavioural disorder
  • The NICE guideline development group (GDG) recommends that specialists (preferably within an autism team) take a lead role in managing children or young people with ASD and an associated mental health or behavioural disorder, due to the complexity of management of these children or young people [National Collaborating Centre for Mental Health, 2013].
Information and support for parents/carers
  • Children and young people with ASD have an enduring condition that can have a significant impact on them and their family and/or carers. The NICE GDG recommends that health professionals should ensure that the parents and/or carers (and, if appropriate, the child or young person) are well informed about their rights and entitlements and about the support available to them.
Sleep problems and behaviour that challenges
  • See the sections on Managing sleep problems and Managing behaviour that challenges for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage sleep problems in a child/young person with autism spectrum disorder?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Identify and refer children or young people with autism spectrum disorder who have a sleep problem caused by:
    • Obstructive sleep apnoea — indicated by loud snoring, choking, or witnessed episodes of apnoea whilst sleeping.
      • If present, refer to a paediatric sleep specialist or respiratory physician.
    • An associated mental health or behavioural disorder — such as anxiety, depression, or attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
      • If present, refer to an autism team if available, or if not, to a paediatrician or a child and adolescent psychiatrist.
    • Medication initiated in secondary care — such as antiepileptics (for example, lamotrigine or phenytoin) or stimulants (for example, methylphenidate).
      • If present, consider referral to the specialist who initiated this treatment.
  • Identify and manage factors contributing to the sleep problem (where possible).
    • Consider the use of a sleep diary to help identify factors contributing to the problem. This should record details about their sleep, and events and activities that occurred while awake, over a two-week period before being reviewed.
    • Factors that may contribute to sleep problems include:
      • A poor sleep environment, for example, due to background noise, room sharing with another child, or the presence of a television or computer in the bedroom.
      • Irregular bedtime patterns, or any recent change to the bedtime pattern.
      • Physical illness or discomfort, for example, abdominal pain, earache, or eczema.
      • Levels of activity and exercise during the day.
      • Emotional upset.
    • The National Autistic Society website (www.autism.org.uk) has information on Sleep disorders.
  • Give advice on good sleep hygiene. See the section on Good sleep hygiene in the CKS topic on Insomnia for more information.
  • If the problem persists, consider referral to a paediatric sleep specialist or an autism team if available (or if not, to a paediatrician or a child and adolescent psychiatrist). Be aware that pharmacological intervention to aid sleep should:
    • Only be used following consultation with a specialist paediatrician or psychiatrist with expertise in the management of autism or paediatric sleep medicine.
    • Be used in conjunction with non-pharmacological interventions.
    • Be regularly reviewed to evaluate the ongoing need for a pharmacological intervention and to ensure that the benefits continue to outweigh the adverse effects and risks.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based largely on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines Autism. The management and support of children and young people on the autism spectrum [National Collaborating Centre for Mental Health, 2013] and Autism spectrum disorder in under 19s: support and management [NICE, 2017], and are based on the expert opinion of the NICE guideline development group (GDG) given a lack of trial evidence. The recommendations are in line with those in the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) guideline Assessment, diagnosis and interventions for autism spectrum disorders [SIGN, 2016].

Referral criteria
  • In the opinion of the NICE GDG, children and young people with suspected sleep apnoea are best managed by a sleep expert. CKS recommends that in the event that a sleep expert is not available, referral should be made to a paediatrician with a special interest in respiratory medicine because they have the appropriate expertise in managing sleep apnoea.
  • NICE recommends that specialists (preferably within an autism team) take a lead role in managing children or young people with autism spectrum disorder and an associated mental health or behavioural disorder due to the complexity of the management of these children or young people.
Identifying and managing factors contributing to sleep problems and advice on good sleep hygiene
  • These are pragmatic recommendations based on what the NICE GDG considers to be good clinical practice.
Pharmacological treatment for sleep disorders
  • This information is based on the NICE guideline [NICE, 2017] and the SIGN guideline [SIGN, 2016].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage behaviour that challenges in a child or young person with autism spectrum disorder?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Consult the care plan (if available) for any advice on managing behaviour that challenges in the child or young person.
  • Assess for:
    • A mental health or behavioural disorder, such as anxiety, depression, or attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. See the CKS topics on Generalized anxiety disorder, Depression in children, and Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder for information on how to assess for these conditions.
      • If suspected, refer to the autism team if available (or if not, to a paediatrician or a child and adolescent psychiatrist [dependant on local referral policy]).
    • Suspected child maltreatment. See the section on Recognizing child maltreatment in the CKS topic on Child maltreatment - recognition and management for more information.
      • If suspected, see the section on Managing a child or young person with suspected maltreatment in the CKS topic on Child maltreatment - recognition and management for more information. 
  • Assess for and manage (where possible):
    • Coexisting physical illness, such as otitis media and gastrointestinal disorders.
    • Communication problems with difficulty in understanding situations or expressing needs and wishes.
      • Consider using visual aids (such as words, pictures, or symbols) that are meaningful to the child or young person to aid communication.
      • The National Autistic Society website (www.autism.org.uk) has information on Visual supports and information on where to find Resources. 
    • Changes in their physical or social environment, routines, or personal circumstances.
      • Advise parents and/or carers to make reasonable adaptations to the amount of personal space given, if this is a problem for the child or young person.
      • Also advise that they should minimize sensory stimulation (for example to light, noise, or colours) if this is a problem for the child or young person.
      • The National Autistic Society website (www.autism.org.uk) has information on Creating an autism friendly space and Funding for home adaptation.
    • Unintentional reinforcement of behaviour that challenges, for example:
      • Inconsistent approaches to behaviour that challenges, or misunderstanding the reason for the behaviour.
      • The National Autistic Society website (www.autism.org.uk) has guidance on managing behaviour that challenges in people with autism, including specific information on the possible reasons for, and suggest strategies to address, Self-injurious behaviour, Physical challenging behaviour (such as biting, spitting, hitting, and hair pulling), Pica (eating or mouthing non-edible items), and Smearing. It also includes information on getting Support.
  • If behaviour that challenges persists despite the above measures, refer to the autism team if available (if not, to a paediatrician or a child and adolescent psychiatrist [dependant on local referral policy]). Be aware that pharmacological intervention for behaviour that challenges:
    • Should only be considered when psychosocial or other interventions are insufficient or could not be delivered because of the severity of the behaviour.
    • Should be initially prescribed and monitored by a paediatrician or psychiatrist who should:
      • Identify the target behaviour.
      • Decide on an appropriate measure to monitor effectiveness, including frequency and severity of the behaviour and a measure of global impact.
      • Review the effectiveness and any adverse effects of the medication after 3–4 weeks.
      • Stop treatment if there is no indication of a clinically important response at 6 weeks.
    • May be continued in primary care under a shared care protocol with clear instructions from the specialist regarding the target behaviour, suggested duration of treatment, plans for stopping, the potential for minimal effective dosing, and how to monitor for beneficial or adverse effects.
      • NHS England (www.england.nhs.uk) has guidance on Stopping Over-Medication of People with a Learning Disability, Autism or Both (STOMP). The aim of the document is to provide GPs with support to begin the process of challenging continued medication use in people with a learning disability, autism, or both.
      • Links to additional STOMP resources for GPs, psychiatrists, psychologists, pharmacists, nurses, and social care providers are available on the Professional resources page on the NHS England website (www.england.nhs.uk).
  • The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) has published guidelines on managing people with learning disabilities and behaviour that challenges:
    • Challenging behaviour and learning disabilities: prevention and interventions for people with learning disabilities whose behaviour challenges covers interventions and support for children, young people, and adults with a learning disability and behaviour that challenges. It also covers support and intervention for family members and/or carers.
    • Learning disabilities and behaviour that challenges: service design and delivery covers services for children, young people, and adults with a learning disability (or autism and a learning disability) and behaviour that challenges.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based largely on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines Autism. The management and support of children and young people on the autism spectrum [National Collaborating Centre for Mental Health, 2013] and Autism spectrum disorder in under 19s: support and management [NICE, 2017], and are based on the expert opinion of the NICE guideline development group (GDG) given a lack of trial evidence. The recommendations are in line with those in the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) guideline Assessment, diagnosis and interventions for autism spectrum disorders [SIGN, 2016].

Consulting the child or young person's care plan
  • NICE recommends that each child or young person with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) should have a care plan which outlines the relevant risk factors for challenging behaviour and how it should be treated or managed.
Referral for children or young people with mental health or behavioural disorders
  • The NICE GDG recommends that specialists (preferably within an autism team) take a lead role in managing children or young people with ASD and an associated mental health or behavioural disorder due to the complexity of management of these children or young people.
Assessing and managing causes of challenging behaviour
  • This recommendation is based on the expert opinion of the NICE GDG. The list of causes includes the most common causes of challenging behaviour in children and young people.
Specialist referral if problems persist
  • Specialist referral for children or young people who have not responded to initial primary care management is a pragmatic recommendation made by the NICE GDG to ensure optimal management of challenging behaviour.
Pharmacological treatment
  • This recommendation is based on the NICE guideline [NICE, 2017] and the SIGN guideline [SIGN, 2016].
  • According to Public Health England (PHE), a substantial proportion of people with a learning disability, autism, or both who are prescribed psychotropic drugs for behavioural purposes can safely have their drugs reduced or withdrawn.
    • The STOMP (Stopping Over-Medication of People with a Learning Disability, Autism or Both) project was launched in 2016 by NHS England, the Royal College of Nursing (RCN), the Royal College of Psychiatrists, the Royal College of GPs (RCGP), the Royal Pharmaceutical Society (RPS), and the British Psychological Society (BPS) to to tackle the over medication of people with a learning disability, autism, or both. These organizations pledged to work together to stop the over medication of people with a learning disability, autism, or both.
      • The children and young people’s team in the learning disability programme is working with the Royal College of Paediatricians and Child Health, and the British Academy of Childhood Disability, to deliver the STOMP message for children and young people.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What is the role of secondary care in the management of children and young people with autism spectrum disorder?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is established by a specialist following referral. Ideally, this is carried out by an autism team if available (or if not, by a child and adolescent psychiatrist or paediatrician [dependant on local referral policy]).
    • The autism team is a multidisciplinary team with the skills and competencies to carry out an autism diagnostic assessment and to communicate with children and young people with suspected or known autism (and with their parents and/or carers) and sensitively share the diagnosis with them.
    • The core members of the autism team should include a paediatrician and/or child and adolescent psychiatrist, speech and language therapist, and a clinical and/or educational psychologist.
    • The team should include or have regular access to a paediatrician or paediatric neurologist, child and adolescent psychiatrist, educational psychologist, clinical psychologist, and occupational therapist, if they are not already in the team. Other healthcare professionals, such as a specialist health visitor or nurse, specialist teacher, or social worker, may be involved on a needs basis.
  • After the diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder is established, the role of the autism team will generally involve (although provision will vary):
    • Developing a care plan tailored to the needs of the child or young person.
    • Identifying a key worker or case manager who will act as the single point of access to the parents and/or carers (or, if appropriate, the child or young person).
    • Offering specialist interventions to support the development of social and communication skills.
    • Considering pharmacological interventions to help manage behaviour that challenges.
      • Pharmacological treatment for behaviour that challenges should only be considered when psychosocial or other interventions are insufficient or could not be delivered because of the severity of the behaviour.
      • The prescribing and monitoring of treatment initiated in secondary care may involve primary care under a shared care protocol with clear instructions from the specialist regarding the target behaviour, suggested duration of treatment, plans for stopping, the potential for minimal effective dosing, and how to monitor for beneficial or adverse effects.
    • Managing children and young people with an associated mental health or developmental disorder, such as anxiety, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, oppositional defiant disorder, and learning (intellectual) disability.
    • Supporting access and maintaining contact with educational, housing, and employment services. They may, with consent of the parents and/or carers (or, if appropriate, the child or young person), share information directly with relevant services, such as schools or social care.
    • Providing information to parents and/or carers (and, if appropriate, the child or young person) on where to access further information, support, and appropriate services.
    • Planning transition into adult services — the young person should be reassessed to establish the need for continuing treatment into adulthood. This assessment should ideally take place around the age of 14 years. If continuing treatment is necessary:
      • Arrangements should be made for a smooth transition to adult services.
      • The young person should be given information on the treatment and services they may need.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This information is based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines Autism spectrum disorder in under 19s: support and management [NICE, 2017], Autism: recognition, referral and diagnosis of children and young people on the autism spectrum [National Collaborating Centre for Women’s and Children’s Health, 2017], and Autism spectrum disorder in under 19s: recognition, referral and diagnosis [NICE, 2017].
